Mon, Sep 28, 2015, 17:08 BST - UK Markets closed Fidelity Special Situations Fund should you invest? By Kyle Caldwell | Telegraph – 10 minutes ago 65.00 -1.5000 
We put the popular Fidelity Special Situations fund, once managed by celebrated investor Anthony Bolton, under the spotlight 
Fidelity Special Situations is one of the most widely held “UK growth” funds, targeting companies that reinvest back into their business rather than paying out profits to shareholders. 
Its popularity is down to the fact that the fund used to be managed by Anthony Bolton, the celebrated investor. 
Today the stock picker at the helm is Alex Wright, who has managed the fund since January 2014. 
Mr Wright, often described as a star fund manager of the future, also manages the Fidelity Special Values investment trust. 
But it is Mr Wright’s other fund, Fidelity UK Smaller Companies, which catches the eye. 
Over the past five years the fund has raced ahead of rivals under Mr Wright’s stewardship, returning nearly 300pc (blue line) since he took over the fund in March 2008. The average smaller company fund is up 100pc (red line) over the same period. 
Fidelity Special Situations splits its money across the market. A third is currently in the FTSE 100 but experts are confident that Mr Wright can deliver the goods with a wider remit. 
= What makes the fund different…. = 
Mr Wright describes himself as a contrarian investor. This means it is Mr Wright’s job to buy shares in which other investors have lost faith, and where further falls should be limited. 
Sectors of the market Mr Wright is currently backing include banks, which he expects will pay juicy dividends in the coming year. Mr Wight owns HSBC, Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) and Lloyds. 
Another area where Mr Wright is finding value is the bombed-out oil sector . 
Mr Wright has bought BG Group (LSE: BG.L - news ) following Royal Dutch Shell (Xetra: R6C1.DE - news ) launching a takeover bid for the firm. Other purchases include small oil companies, such as Nostrum and Faroe Petroleum (LSE: FPM.L - news ) , which operates in the North Sea.

= What the experts think…. = 
Ben Willis, of Whitechurch Securities, the wealth manager, said: “Mr Wright looks to tap into what he perceives as undervalued UK companies. His stock picking outside the FTSE 100 has produced some excellent returns and this is where he adds value.”
